comment.author: 77235581@N00
comment._content:
From CWGC website: 
Second Lieutenant JAMES DOUGLAS HERBERT FARMER
Son of James Herbert and Edith Gertrude Farmer, of "Fairfield," Mundesley, Norfolk.
9th Bty. 41st Bde. Royal Field Artillery
Ypres (Menin Gate) memorial, panel 5 and 9

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: The CWGC does not list an Eksternest cemetery but Eksternest is near Zonnebeke, Belgium. A map of Flanders here www.ww1battlefields.co.uk/flanders.html shows the location of many of the WWI battlefield locations in the Ypres area, with the modern roads marked.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: According to the family tree of C Gorman at wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=DESC&db=:... JAMES DOUGLAS HERBERT FARMER was born 2 Dec 1892, KIA 2 Nov 1914. His four siblings carried 'Herbert' before 'Farmer' in their name.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Probably killed during the First Battle of Ypres 19 Oct-22 Nov 1914. Between the actions at Gheluvelt, a German attack to break through between Hytschaete and Messines, and a final attempt to take Ypres from along the line of the Menin Road, by 1st November both British and German forces in this area had taken desperately high casualties and fought themselves to a point of exhaustion.  4th November 1914 is described as a day of menaces rather than attacks, nevertheless 2nd Division, of which XLI Arty Bde RFA was a part, was subjected to increasingly heavy German shelling.

9th Field Battery was a Regular RFA battery based in peacetime 1914 in Bordon, Hampshire - with 16 Field Battery and 17 Field Battery formed XLI Artillery Brigade which on 4 Nov 14 was commanded by Lt Col Stephen Lushington RA (born 1864 and educated at Eton).  XLI Bde RFA arrived in France in August 1914, fought with distinction extracting 4th Guards Bde at Villers-Cotteret on 1 Sep 14 although 'under an infernal fire', and again supporting 2nd Bn Worcestershires at Polygon Wood at the end of October.//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: James Douglas Herbert Farmer, a Gentleman Cadet at the Royal Military Academy, was Commissioned into the Royal Regiment of Artillery as a Second Lieutenant in the Regular Army on 13th July 1913.  London Gazette 28747 of 19 Aug 1913.//

comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content: As well as appearing on the Roll of Honour in All Saints, Mundesley, there is a separate plaque commemorating the loss just inside the church door. There is a picture of James on Norlink norlink.norfolk.gov.uk/02_Catalogue/02_013_PictureTitleIn... The picture has what looks like a clipping attached, “FARMER - Killed in action, on 4th November, Second Lieut. James Douglas Herbert Farmer, Royal Artillery, the dearly loved second son of James Herbert Farmer of “Fairfield”, Mundesley, Norfolk and grandson of the late James Farmer Esq. J P and the late Sir George Harris J.P. L.C.C, aged 21” Underneath is a hand-written note - “Gazetted July 1913”. James Douglas Herbert has an entry in De Ruvigny’s but not in the two volumes I have a copy of. Working through the other names above, there are Medal Index Cards for Frederick Spencer Herbert, initially Second Lieutenant than Lieutenant, 3rd Battalion attached 2nd Battalion, Norfolk Regiment before becoming a Lieutenant with the 17th Special Battalion , (which is a new unit on me and doesn’t appear in any of the normal lists). discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/Details?uri=D2... Charles Robert Herbert, initially Second Lieutenant, 15th Hussars before becoming a Lieutenant in the 18th Hussars and attached to the Motor Machine Gun Section. discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/Details?uri=D2... No obvious candidate for the Naval Officer either in the normal service or the Volunteer Reserve.. As we have a George Adderley Herbert on the 1911 census, he would be a prime candidate for the Honourable Artillery Company man. There is a George A H Farmer who was Private 12420 Honourable Artillery Company Infantry. discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/Details?uri=D2...
